Social distancing measures and masks are recommended in formal and informal education. Participants in informal education, hobby activities, refresher training and youth work who are over 18 years of age have to present a valid COVID certificate proving vaccination or recovery.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211128160608/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/education-pre-schools-hobby-education-sport-continuous-education/restrictions-in-education-youth-work-hobby-and-sports-activities

Workplaces are open but the employers must evaluate the risks present in the working environment and enact measures to lower the risks: these measures can include requirement to wear a mask, testing, vaccination, re-organisation of work, etc.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115161323/https://www.kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/working-workplace

Since January 6th 2022, the country went into high risk level for covid-19 which means that distance working is highly recommended, in addition to the previous existing measures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115161323/https://www.kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/working-workplace  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115162302/https://kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/levels-risk  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115162911/https://www.kriis.ee/en/news/risk-level-spread-coronavirus-became-very-high-again

Participants over the age of 12 must present a covid certificate, else they cannot participate.   Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors. Events must end before 11pm.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115155930/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

Participants over the age of 12 must present a covid certificate. People without covid certificate cannot participate in public gatherings.   Provided that the organiser ensures that the infection risk status of all the participants is checked, up to 1000 people may participate indoors and up to 2 000 people outdoors.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115155930/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

Masks must be worn on public transport and hygiene measures are recommended  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115161435/https://www.kriis.ee/en/everyday-life-and-services/services/public-transport-and-getting-around
No stay at home requirement   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115155930/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions
No restriction on internal movement  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115155930/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

Depending of the country of origin, the list of requirement changes. Travelers might have to get tested, self-isolate and might need to present an imperial reason to be allowed to enter Estonia (work, studying, family reasons, or under a special permit).   https://web.archive.org/web/20220115162910/https://www.kriis.ee/en/travelling-crossing-state-border/travelling-estonia/who-subject-restrictions
No income support provided, only sick days   https://web.archive.org/web/20211128162108/https://www.kriis.ee/en/work-life-and-being-away-work/employee/sick-days-certificates-care-leave
No policy found  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115155930/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions
A coordinated public campaign of information exists, notably through an updated government website.   https://web.archive.org/web/20211221140933/https://kriis.ee/en

In most cases, family physicians or the Health Board must refer their patients to testing. Specific providers can also provide tests for a fee to anyone who wants to be tested.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211212203305/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/testing-for-the-virus
Contact tracing is done through the HOIA app   https://web.archive.org/web/20211212203516/https://kkk.kriis.ee/en/faq/coronavirus-infection-close-contact-and-virus-spread/hoia-mobile-app

A mask must be worn by all persons 12 years of age and older in all indoor spaces meant for public use  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115155930/https://www.kriis.ee/en/crisis-management-qa/crisis-management/current-restrictions

All residents of Estonia from the age of 12 are expected to get vaccinated for free against COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211128160602/https://www.kriis.ee/en/sickness-health-vaccinations/vaccines-and-vaccinations/covid-19-vaccines

Recommendations are made to protect elderly people.   Where possible, home-based services provided for the elderly by the local government of residence should be preferred to placement in a nursing home.  Residents of nursing homes should not be transferred between different homes.  Before meeting a person at risk, make sure you are safe from infection and ensure safety when meeting them: wear a mask, keep your distance, and clean your hands and surfaces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220115164650/https://www.kriis.ee/en/sickness-health-vaccinations/coronavirus-and-preventing-its-spread/prevention-coronavirus

The Nationwide Telework recommendation has now been reintroduced in areas currently experiencing increased levels of community transmission.   The recommendation is for all employees in the public sector to work remotely as extensively as possible if their duties so allow. The Government also recommends that private employers adopt similar extensive remote work practices, recognising, however, that workplaces will determine how to combine in-office and remote work in a way that ensures health security.     Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20211216145328/https://valtioneuvosto.fi/en/-/10623/government-recommends-remote-work-in-areas-in-the-community-transmission-phase-until-further-notice

Vaccinated travelers from all countries are now permitted to enter Finland. However, this requires having received the last dose of a valid COVID-19 vaccine at least 14 days prior to arrival. People coming in from countries marked as risk countries who do no not have a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test, proof of having had the disease or a vaccination certificate, would have to be tested for COVID-19 on entry into the country. This test is mandatory    Archived: https://archive.vn/SVEDj

The requirements for entry into Finland include the following:   - a certificate of a full approved COVID-19 vaccination series, OR  - a certificate of having had the COVID-19 disease and one approved COVID-19 vaccine, OR  - an EU Digital COVID Certificate for a COVID-19 disease had less than six months ago, AND  - a certificate of a negative COVID-19 test taken no earlier than 48 hours before arrival in Finland.    These requirements apply to those born in or before 2006. They however do not apply to citizens of Finland, those with permanent residence in Finland or persons travelling for essential reasons. Those who do not meet the requirement are required to have a mandatory covid test.    Archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20220106182331/https://thl.fi/en/web/infectious-diseases-and-vaccinations/what-s-new/coronavirus-covid-19-latest-updates/travel-and-the-coronavirus-pandemic

A mobile app "Koronavilkku",  is a contact tracing app was produced by the Finnish Institute for Health and Welfare (THL) to help people find out whether you may have been exposed to coronavirus. The app can also be used to send share positive tests results anonymously with those you have been in close contact with. Overall policy remains broadly similar to that introduced on 9 December 2021, but isolation and testing rules to be followed after the detection of a case of Covid-19 in a class have been modified from 3 January 2022 per https://web.archive.org/web/20220105124117/https://www.gouvernement.fr/les-regles-d-isolement-en-vigueur-en-milieu-scolaire-depuis-le-3-janvier     https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050328/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No change in policy - https://web.archive.org/web/20220114193949/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

Covid-19 protocols in schools have been simplified in order to allow education facilities to remain open. The following regulations, announced by the Prime Minister on 10 January, take effect as of 14 January:     - When a positive case is detected in a class, parents will no longer be asked to pick up their child immediately, they can wait for the end of the school day.  - When a positive case is detected in a classroom, case contacts aged under 12 years or those aged over 12 who have a complete vaccination schedule will be able to use 3 free self-tests provided by pharmacies, and will no longer have to perform a PCR or antigen test followed by two self-tests).  - Parents will no longer be asked to produce a certificate after each self-test: a single certificate will be requested. Children may not attend school if one of the self-tests is positive.     Additional measures were announced by the Minister of Education, Youth and Sports on 13 January, including:     - the distribution of 5 million FFP2 masks in establishments for staff who feel the need;  - the replenishment of the fund for the purchase of CO2 sensors as much as necessary, so that local authorities can request it even more massively.  - the recruitment of 3,300 more contract workers;  - the use of supplementary lists;  - the recruitment of educational assistants and support staff for school principals.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220114193949/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education
No policy changes - https://web.archive.org/web/20220121172851/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/education

From 3 January, the use of telework will be made compulsory for all employees for whom it is possible, at a minimum of three days per week and four days when possible. Discotheques and nightclubs are joined by standing concerts in being banned until at least 24 January, and those workplaces are thus closed. https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050347/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus    National guidelines to ensure health and safety of employees were updated on 3 January, available at https://web.archive.org/web/20220103115103/https://www.gouvernement.fr/le-protocole-national-pour-assurer-la-sante-et-la-securite-des-salaries-en-entreprise-au-3-janvier

From 6 January, the classification of countries returns to the 3-stage system of Green/Orange/Red with the elimination of the temporary fourth "Scarlet Red" category. Countries of the travellers origin are categorised as follows:     "Green" countries/territories: countries/territories in which no active circulation of the virus is observed and no variants of concern are identified. These are the countries of the European area, to which are added Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, South Korea, The United Arab Emirates, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, Taiwan, Uruguay and Vanuatu.    "Orange" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus is observed in controlled proportions. These are all countries/territories not included in the lists of "green" and "red" countries/territories. Reinforced measures are in force for travel between France and the United Kingdom. The Travel Advice sheet for the United Kingdom should be consulted.    "Red" countries/territories: countries/territories in which active circulation of the virus with the presence of variants of concern is observed. These are: Afghanistan, Belarus, Botswana, the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Georgia, Lesotho, Malawi, Mauritius, Moldova, Montenegro, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, Pakistan, Russia, South Africa, Suriname, Tanzania, Turkey, Ukraine, the United States, Zambia and Zimbabwe.    All passengers from Red list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding and may be tested again on arrival. Unvaccinated passengers are subject to presentation of "compelling reasons" for travel, mandatory antigen testing on arrival, and must quarantine for 10 days under the control of security forces.     Passengers from Orange list countries must present negative results of a PCR or antigen test taken in the previous 48 hours at boarding. Vaccinated passengers are not subject to the "compelling reasons" regime, but unvaccinated people are and must commit to self-isolation lasting 7 days and undergo testing at the end of this period.     Although an Orange list country, additional regulations apply to all passengers aged 12 or over arriving from the United Kingdom:     - subject to the list of "compelling reasons"  - must present a negative PCR or antigenic (TAG) test taken less than 24 hours before the flight on boarding ;  - must register before departure on the eOS-COVID digital platform  ;  - may be tested antigen on arrival ;  - will be subject to mandatory isolation for 10 days,supervised and controlled by the security forces. This isolation obligation may be lifted from 48 hours, subject to being able to justify a negative test (PCR or TAG).    Specific guidance for UK passengers is available at https://web.archive.org/web/20220108054040/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/conseils-par-pays-destination/royaume-uni/    Passengers from Green List countries are divided into two groups:     1. Member States of the European Union, Andorra, Iceland, Liechtenstein, Monaco, Norway, San Marino, the Holy See and Switzerland - Travelers twelve years of age or older who do not have proof of a complete vaccination schedule or a certificate of recovery from Covid-19 must present before travel the negative result of a test (PCR or antigenic) of less than 24 hours. They may be tested for antigen on arrival.    2. Argentina, Australia, Bahrain, Hong Kong, Japan, Kuwait, New Zealand, Qatar, Rwanda, Saudi Arabia, Senegal, South Korea, Taiwan, The United Arab Emirates, Uruguay and Vanuatu:  All travelers twelve years of age or older, regardless of their vaccination status,from these countries/territories must present for boarding, the negative result of a PCR test or an antigen test (TAG) carried out less than 48 hours before the flight.     https://web.archive.org/web/20220108050616/https://www.diplomatie.gouv.fr/fr/conseils-aux-voyageurs/informations-pratiques/article/coronavirus-covid-19

From 22 December, vaccination is universally available to people aged over 5 years and older.    Vaccination booster is available to all people aged 18 and over from five months after the last injection and one month after the second injection, or five months after recovery from infection with Covid-19.    As of December 15, 2021, the rules relating to the "health pass" are changing for people aged 65 and over, and people vaccinated with Janssen. From this date, these people must have received their booster vaccination, from the moment they are eligible (5 months after their last injection for the first and 1 month for the second), and at the end of a period of 8 additional weeks maximum.    People aged 80 and over with mobility issues are eligible for home vaccination visits.     The Pfizer/BioNTech, Moderna, AstraZeneca/Vaxzevria/Covishield and Johnson & Johnson vaccines are authorised for use in France.     https://web.archive.org/web/20211224120928/https://www.gouvernement.fr/info-coronavirus/vaccins

All travellers 12 years and older are required to get tested for COVID-19 upon arrival in the Faroe Islands. Younger travellers can voluntarily get tested.  All travellers are recommended to home quarantine until the result from the PCR test from the second day after arrival is available.  If you arrive from a âhigh-riskâ country, you should home quarantine for seven days. This period can be shortened if you can show a negative PCR test result taken no more than six days after arrival in the Faroes.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211222162315/https://korona.fo/270?_l=en  https://web.archive.org/web/20220104081708/https://korona.fo/travel?_l=en

Greece will reopen schools as scheduled on Monday amid record coronavirus cases, the government has decided.    Schools will reopen on Jan. 10 with stricter testing protocols as ânothing can replace live teaching for the psycho-emotional development of our children,â Education Minister Niki Kerameus said Tuesday.    https://web.archive.org/web/%2A/https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2022-01-04/greece-to-reopen-schools-as-planned-on-monday-amid-record-cases

Greece reintroduced measures aimed at curbing the spread of the coronavirus pandemic amid concern that rising cases will pile pressure on the nationâs health care system.    As much as 50% of all private and public-sector employees will have to work from home between Jan. 3 and Jan. 16, Health Minister Athanasios Plevris said Monday. The government also ordered restaurants, bars, cafes and night clubs to close at midnight.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161816/https://www.bloomberg.com/tosv2.html?vid=&uuid=ea7e0e9d-7230-11ec-a53d-5a7175777570&url=L25ld3MvYXJ0aWNsZXMvMjAyMS0xMi0yNy9ncmVlY2UtcmVpbnN0YXRlcy13b3JrLWZyb20taG9tZS1tYW5kYXRlLW5pZ2h0LWxpZmUtY3VyYnM=

no policy change     Unless all passengers are members of the same family, a maximum of 3 persons are permitted to travel in a taxi or other private vehicle with up to 7 seats, or 4 persons in a private vehicle with up to 9 seats;  Cross-regional travel is allowed for mainland Greece and the islands of Lefkada, Evia and Salamina (use of self-tests ahead of travel is strongly recommended but is not mandatory).  Cross-regional travel to the rest of the islands is permitted but only with either:    proof of vaccination and 14 days since second dose (see Demonstrating your COVID-19 vaccination status), or  a negative result from a PCR test carried out up to 72 hours prior to travel; or  a negative result from a rapid test or self-test conducted up to 24 hours before travel; or  a self-test declaration signed less than 24 hours before travel; or  documentary proof of having recovered from Covid-19 (at least 2 months since infection, and no more than 9 months)  Travel in Greece  Travel within Greece between Regional Units is permitted subject to adherence to public health measures as outlined above. You must wear a mask at all times on all public transport.    If you are travelling via ferry, you will need to complete a health questionnaire and hand it to the ferry operator before boarding. The necessary forms will be provided by the operator: you should contact them directly if you need further information. Temperature checks may also be carried out before boarding.    If you are travelling by internal (domestic) flights, specific measures relating to check-in, baggage allowances and other details are in place to reduce the spread of coronavirus. You should check with your operator directly for further detail.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210802101710/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/greece/coronavirus

All those travelling to Greece (aged 5 or above) must show proof of a professionally administered negative rapid COVID-19 test taken no more than 24 hours before arrival or proof of a professionally administered negative PCR test taken no more than 72 hours before arrival.     The measure affects all arrivals, regardless of vaccination status or country of departure. The only exception is for arrivals who have spent less than 48 hours in a country prior to arriving in Greece.                                              Random antigen testing on arrival applies to every arrival to Greece, regardless of the certificate in their possession. If you are selected, please keep in mind that the screening is mandatory and in case of refusal, authorities reserve the right to refuse entry into the country.    If you are selected for a test and test positive, you will be subject to mandatory quarantine, for which you may be required by the Greek authorities to move to a designated quarantine facility.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220110161137/https://www.dfa.ie/travel/travel-advice/a-z-list-of-countries/greece/

Guidelines for primary schools, day care institutions and recreational activities:  -In the case of infection at schools and institutions etc., it will most often be other contacts that are of concern.  -Children, who are other contacts to an infected person (child or employee) in a day-care nursery etc., in school (including boarding schools and private schools) or in connection with recreational activities, must follow the recommendations for other contacts. In order to adapt as much as possible to the new conditions, employers are advised to organize, wherever possible, work from home or work in shifts, in order to avoid interference by workers. For the protection of one's own, but also the health of others, it is recommended that all business trips be postponed and that meetings be held online. Jobs related to the health care system also have specially prescribed measures that employees must adhere to so that the system itself is not overloaded. All recommendations for employees and employers in trade, catering facilities, measures for drivers in road freight transport or employees in the state administration, can be found here.    https://web.archive.org/web/20211112163018/https://www.koronavirus.hr/sto-moram-znati/o-poslu/46

Restrictions for Individuals and Businesses  Businesses and individuals may be restricted due to the epidemiological measures based on your location in Croatia.    As of January 10, 2022, the Government of Croatia is imposing a range of epidemiological measures:    Indoor public gatherings are limited to 25 people.  Outdoor public gatherings are limited to no more than 50 people.  Outdoor public gatherings where everyone has EU digital certificates are limited to 200.  Private ceremonies will be limited to 20. Exception: private ceremonies in which everyone has a covid certificate will be limited to 50 people.  Sporting events and competitions: Indoor sports facilities may operate with up to 20 percent of spectator seating occupied. Outdoor events may operate with up to 40 percent of spectator seating occupied.  Catering / Dining establishments will be under more robust and compliance checks.  Individual counties and cities may have additional measures. Please visit?the?Croatian Governmentâs COVID-19 website?for additional information.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125001728/https://hr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Entry rules in response to coronavirus  Entry to Croatia  To be allowed entry into Croatia, all travellers from the UK must present one of the following documents on arrival:    proof of a vaccination, not older than 365 days, or;  a negative COVID-19 antigen not older than 48 hours, or;  a negative PCR test result not older than 72 hours, or;  a doctorâs certificate of recovery from COVID-19. (See âDemonstrating your COVID-19 statusâ).  Children under 12 and accompanied by a parent or guardian are exempt from these requirements if the parent or guardian has one of the documents set out above.    You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    Details of further exemptions from the requirements set out above are available here and include for example passengers transiting Croatia in under 12 hours.    If you are arriving in Croatia from countries other than the UK, Cyprus, Russia, South Africa, Brazil or Zanzibar and do not have one of the documents listed above, and are not subject to a specific exemption, you will be required to take a PCR test or rapid antigen test upon arrival in Croatia. You will need to self-isolate until the results of a negative test are received. Upon entry to Croatia, you will be handed instructions regarding the conditions for self isolation, which will include details about ending your self-isolation through a negative test. See more information about testing centres in Croatia.    If you travel to another country after receiving a negative PCR (72 hours validity) test or rapid antigen test (48 hours validity) in Croatia and return back to Croatia within less than 48 or 72 hours (for PCR) from the date of testing, you will not be required to provide a new test from the country you travelled to.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220125002528/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/croatia/entry-requirements

The government is providing several significant subsidies.  Parents receive a family tax refund. In February 2022, parents raising a child will be refunded their income tax paid in 2021 up to the tax level of the average wage.  Retirees received a larger-than-ever pension premium  of HUF 80,000 in November and will receive a full refund  of their 13-month pension  in February 2022.  Wage increases will continue: from January 2022, the minimum wage will be HUF 200,000 and the guaranteed minimum wage will be HUF 260,000,  thus the minimum wage will be higher from 2022 onwards.  Young people under the age of  25 will not have to pay income tax  from January 2022.  The credit moratorium was extended until June 30, 2022. Those who are expecting and raising a child, retirees, and those in public employment can continue to take advantage of the opportunity, as can businesses and individuals whose incomes have fallen significantly from the previous year.  Source: https://archive.vn/3JHc5

15th Jan 2022, Everyone should work from home unless it is necessary to attend the workplace in person.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121175253/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/3361b-public-health-updates/

Family and social gatherings  People should limit their contacts throughout the coming period to the greatest degree possible and visits to private homes should be kept to a maximum of 3 other households (that is, 4 households in total).    Hospitality  All restaurants, bars and cafes, excluding take away or delivery services, close at 8pm. This also applies to hotel restaurants and bars, except for overnight residents.    Strict social distancing is required in all bars and restaurants, including hotels (reverting to pre-22 October measures):    COVID pass required  table service only (no counter service)  1 metre between tables  maximum 6 adults per table (maximum 15 persons when including children aged 12 and younger)  no multiple table bookings and no intermingling  masks when not seated at table  Nightclubs are closed.    You may be asked for contact tracing data (for example: name, contact number).    Indoor events  No indoor events, including entertainment, cultural, community and sporting events, will take place after 8pm. In relation to events happening earlier in the day, attendance should be limited to 50% of venue capacity or 1,000 attendees, whichever is the lower. This includes cinemas. This does not affect religious, educational or normal workplace business activity and business events (for example: conferences, trade fairs).    You may be asked for contact tracing data (for example: name, contact number).    Wedding receptions can take place with a capacity limit of 100 guests and continue after 8pm. Midnight closing time still applies.    Religious services  Religious services can proceed without capacity limits but with all other protective measures remaining in place.    Outdoor events  Attendance at outdoor events, including entertainment, cultural, community and sporting events, should be limited to 50% of venue capacity or 5,000 attendees, whichever is the lower.    Group activities  Organisers of indoor and outdoor group activities should ensure that appropriate protective measures are in place, and where indoor groups have a mix of vaccinated and unvaccinated people indoors, pods of 6 should apply.    For children under 18, the âpod of 6â system can be adjusted to allow for indoor games and competition activities only, with all other protective measures remaining in place.    The âpod of 6â system should be retained for all other settings such as training activities and games as part of training. Fixed capacity limits will not apply to these indoor and outdoor group activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121175253/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/3361b-public-health-updates/

On 21 January 2022, the Government announced a plan for easing COVID-19 restrictions.    From 6am on 22 January 2022:    - Pubs and restaurants can return to normal opening times (no longer must close at 8pm)  - Nightclubs can reopen  - You no longer need a vaccination or recovery certificate to access hospitality or indoor activites  - Social distancing is no longer required in hospitality or other settings  - Restrictions on numbers attending indoor and outdoor events or activities no longer apply  - Limits on household visits no longer apply    https://web.archive.org/web/20220103083837/https://www.citizensinformation.ie/en/covid19/living_with_covid19_plan.html

The âpod of 6â system should be retained for all other settings such as training activities and games as part of training. Fixed capacity limits will not apply to these indoor and outdoor group activities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121175253/https://www.gov.ie/en/publication/3361b-public-health-updates/

7/1/22  The social distance between individuals is increased to 2 metres.  The use of face masks is compulsory in places where the 2-m social distance cannot be guaranteed; these include shops.  At events: A maximum of 20 persons may occupy each separate area, sitting in numbered seats allocated to them by name.  Sports that do not involve physical contact, in which it is possible to observe the 2-m social distance and a maximum of 20 participants in each separate area, are permitted, both indoors and out of doors.  Notwithstanding the 2-metre social distance requirement, physical contact is permitted between sportsmen at practices and in competitions held by the National Olympic and Sports Association of Iceland (ÃSÃ), but they are to observe the 2-m social distance rule in changing rooms and other parts of the premises when not taking part in competitions or practices. Notwithstanding the general maximum of 20 persons, up to 50 persons may gather at practices and competitions organised by the Association.    No spectators are permitted at sporting events, either indoors or out of doors.  Sports and fitness activities: Subject to certain conditions, sports and fitness activities may be organised and pursued providing that these are structured group sessions in which all participants are registered, the maximum size of each group being 20 persons. In these cases, the 2-metre social distance rule shall be observed, participants may not exchange equipment during the session and all equipment shall be disinfected between sessions. Shared use of equipment that is fixed to the floor, ceiling or wall, or of large items of equipment (e.g. in fitness and body-building centres) is prohibited.    https://archive.fo/7O6wC

16/01/22  Current restrictions on school activities  The regulation issued by the Minister of Health on the restriction of school activities due to stricter infection prevention measures is effective until 2 February 2022.    Preschools and day-care parents  Maximum number of employees in each area: 20.  Minimum distance between employees: 2 metres.  Use of masks by employees: Where a 2-metre distance limit between employees is not possible. There is no mask obligation in communication with preschool children.  Transfer of employees between groups: Allowed.  Maximum number of children in each area: 50.  Minimum distance between children: None.  Use of face masks by children: None.  Outside area: no limits to the number of people.    Events related to the work or social activities of preschools, such as plays and concerts, may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.      Primary schools and after-school activities  Grades 1 to 10    Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between employees: 2 metres.  Use of masks by employees: Where a 2-metre distance limit between employees and towards students is not possible.  Transfer of employees and students between groups: Allowed.  Maximum number of children in each area: 50.  Minimum distance between children: 1 metre in classrooms.  Use of face masks by children: None.  Physical education and school swimming lessons: Allowed.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.  Outdoor area: No restrictions, but efforts should be made to limit the number of students in each outdoor area unless it impedes outdoor activities.    The restrictions on the number of people do not apply on the school bus.    Events related to the work or social activities of primary schools, such as lectures, reading competitions, etc., may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    After-school activities  The same restrictions apply as apply to preschools and primary schools. One individual is allowed to accompany a child of a preschool age in after-school activities.    Events related to the work or social activities of primary schools, such as plays and concerts, lectures, reading competitions, etc., may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    Mixing between groups: Allowed.    Music schools  All music lessons for children at a preschool and primary school age is permitted with the same restrictions as apply to their school activities.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Students born in 2005 and earlier, as well as employees, should wear masks if social distancing rules cannot be followed, if possible.  Transfer of employees between areas: Allowed.  Maximum number of students in an area: 50.  Studentsâ social distancing rules: Follow the rules for each school level.    Events related to the work or social activities of music schools, such as concerts, may not be attended by anyone other than students and teachers.    Upper secondary schools  Maximum number of employees and students in an area: 50.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Where a 2-metre distance is not possible.  In classrooms, it is permitted to have a distance of 1 metre between students, but then the use of a face mask is required.  Transfer of employees and students between groups: Allowed.  Physical education: Allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.    In situations where it is not possible to enforce social distancing, such as in practical teaching, art teaching and teaching students in vocational training, students and teachers must wear a face mask.  Students may stay in a dormitory.  Events not related to teaching or education are not to be conducted on the school premises.  Events related to work or social activities in upper secondary school are subject to the provisions on performing arts in the regulation on the restrictions on gatherings due to a pandemic.    Universities  Maximum number of employees and students per room: 50.  Maximum number of employees in an area: 20.  Minimum distance between individuals: 2 metres.  Use of face masks: Where a 2-metre distance is not possible.  In classrooms, it is permitted to have a distance of 1 metre between students, but then the use of a mask is required.  Transfer between groups: Allowed.  Physical education: Allowed with the same restrictions as other teaching measures.  Maximum number of students in cafeteria: 50.  Shared areas (entrances, foyers, lavatories and hallways): Restrictions on the number of persons present may be waived if employees use face masks.  In situations where it is not possible to enforce social distancing, such as in practical teaching, art teaching and clinical studies, school work is permitted as long as infection prevention measures are followed and on the condition that students and teachers wear a face mask.    Other events not related to teaching or education are not to be conducted on the school premises.  This provision does not prevent students from staying in dormitories.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220116174134/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/effective-restrictions

?10/1/2022  Managers are responsible for informing their employees of the workplaceâs response plan and what rules apply to its operation while the COVID-19 precautionary measures remain in effect. The need for meetings must be assessed, particularly if there are many attendees. Such meetings should preferably be held using teleconferencing equipment whenever possible. This also applies to meetings within the company if possible. Care must be taken as regards employee travel overseas. Then ecessity of travel must be assessed each time, and employees should avoid such travel unless it is unavoidable.    It is important that managers encourage their employees to take care of their health and to stay at home if they experience any illness. Employees with underlying illnesses are particularly at risk from the virus and should, therefore, consult with their superior as to the possibility of working from home as much as possible if that is an option.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110105656/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/workplaces

Note that self-tests are not accepted.  b) or a recent COVID-19 infection (older than 14 days but not older than 180 days). 10/1/2022  Three types of COVID-tests are in use. PCR-tests are used by the health care system to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, and when people might be infected.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211219162808/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/testing-due-to-symptoms    Additional information  Announcements  Isolation ends  January 8, 2022  Due to the heavy workloads at LandspÃ­tali's Covid outpatient ward and the Civil Protection's Tracing Team, the Chief Epidemiologist has announced that those who have already completed seven days of isolation, do not experience any symptoms of COVID-19 and have not been able to contact the covid outpatient ward, can and may discharge themselves.    There is no need to try to contact the outpatient ward. Only those who are experiencing worsening symptoms need to contact the ward.    As before, day zero is the day an individual takes a PCR test, which is positive. Neither a positive at-home test nor a rapid antigen test can be used as a benchmark for day zero.    As previously stated, the amended rules came into force yesterday, regarding quarantine for those who have received a booster dose and are exposed to COVID-19. For emphasis, this applies to everyone who is in quarantine, including those who are in the same place as an infected individual.    It is important to keep in mind that those who do not have to meet the previous conditions of quarantine must nevertheless meet certain conditions (see also below) and take a PCR test on the fifth day from the date of exposure.  We must continue to look after vulnerable groups in society and pursue individual infection control measures as never before.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220110112145/https://www.covid.is/announcements

16/01/22  Three types of COVID-tests are in use. PCR-tests are used by the health care system to test people with COVID-19 symptoms, and when people might be infected. Rapid antigen tests are also used in the health care system and by certified test centers, both before events, but also at the beginning and end of special precaution. Self-tests people can buy in stores are not deemed reliable. A postitive result should always be confirmed with a PCR test.    Information on centres for COVID-19 PCR or rapid antigen tests  PCR-test - Symptom testing:  If you have symptoms or suspect you have an infection, you should be tested even if you have been vaccinated.  Stay at home and register immediately for testing on My Page at Heilsuvera. If you do not have an electronic ID, you can contact, by telephone, your local healthcare centre, LÃ¦knavaktin 1700 (the on-call medical hotline) or the Heilsuvera online chat. If you have not been in contact with someone infected you are not obliged to islolate until a negative test result is obtained. However it is important to be mindful of social distancing and handwashing and to use a mask if it is nessessary to be around others. You should not, under any circumstances, visit your healthcare centre, the LSH Emergency Unit or LÃ¦knavaktin if you have symptoms, without calling first and receiving advice.  PCR-tests are also used for shortened quarantine. See below.  The symptoms may seem minor but it is still important to be tested, no matter how small they seem.  Symptom testing is always free of charge, for tourists as well.  Rapid antigen test - testing for asymptomatic people  Rapid antigen tests are used to screen for COVID-19 virus with asymptomatic people. If you suspect you have an infection, you should have a PCR-test.  Self-tests  Self-tests are not deemed reliable. If you test positive on a self-test, you should go for a PCR test (free) immediatly and follow the rules on isolation until your results are ready.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220116183316/https://www.covid.is/sub-categories/testing-due-to-symptoms

10/1/2022  You quarantine if:  You've been in a relationship with someone who turned out to be infected.  You are traveling abroad and do not have a vaccination certificate or previous COVID-19 infection.  You do not quarantine if:  You've been with someone who was later quarantined.  Your neighbor is infected (for example, in the same stairwell), unless you have been in a lot of contact.  Quarantine ends:  Quarantine can be shortened to 5 days if you go for sampling, otherwise quarantine is 14 days.  You will automatically receive a barcode for the sampling, you do not need to register specifically for it.  A quarantine that takes place in a home where someone is in isolation ends with a negative result from sampling after the isolation has been lifted. Households can then expect a quarantine day longer than isolation lasts. In order to fulfill the conditions for shortening the quarantine to 5 days, there must be a complete separation between the person in isolation and the person in the quarantine.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211206184014/https://www.covid.is/undirflokkar/sottkvi

no changes in policy, green passes are still required for university students.    Starting September 1st green passes are required for School Personnel only. All students are exempted from this requirement for the time being until and including high school. University students though need to have green passes in order to access the facilities of their university. Universities hence are virtually closed for students without a green pass.    Starting Dec 6th a vaccine mandate is in place for all school personnel.   University students still need to hold a green pass to attend lessons in presence.    http://web.archive.org/web/20211210170128/https://www.wired.it/article/green-pass-scuola-universita-regole-vaccino-mezzi/

no change in policy  since October 15th green passes are mandatory to all workers needing to enter most workplaces, hence such workplaces are virtually closed for those who don't have a green pass.  Super Green Pass (green pass only for the vaccinated or recovered from covid, tests are not part of such green pass) will not be required in most workplaces until Feb 15th. Vaccine mandates are only in place for healthcare workers, LTCF , law enforcement and school personnel.  From Dec 30th to Jan 31st Discos will remain closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20211225114530/https://www.adnkronos.com/decreto-natale-2021-gazzetta-ufficiale-misure-in-vigore-da-oggi-25-dicembre_2rNEica7wfGueXqdc4pPve  https://web.archive.org/web/20211230163709/https://www.ilrestodelcarlino.it/cronaca/super-green-pass-lavoro-trasporti-1.7198595  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106183345/https://tg24.sky.it/cronaca/2022/01/06/covid-decreto-super-green-pass-dove-serve#04  https://web.archive.org/web/20211015175921/https://tg24.sky.it/cronaca/2021/10/15/green-pass-covid-oggi-15-ottobre-diretta    New directives for Green Pass in workplaces are summarized in this table: https://web.archive.org/web/20220102070246/https://www.governo.it/sites/governo.it/files/documenti/documenti/Notizie-allegati/tabella_attivita_consentite.pdf

Although the methodology to perform contact tracing has not changed (all close contacts need to be tested or self-quarantine if they don't want to be tested), since the end of December contact tracing has been struggling to trace all close contacts of positives. With very high positive numbers (around 219000 on January 6th) and over a million tests performed most days, the tracing methodology is struggling to function and test everyone: long queues have been forming to get tested as well as long delays to get the results.  It seems the tracing methodology is still comprehensive though so marking as such  https://web.archive.org/web/20211228213909/https://gazzettadelsud.it/articoli/cronaca/2021/12/28/covid-tracciamento-dei-contatti-e-file-per-i-tamponi-il-sistema-e-andato-in-tilt-0f087917-40ef-4c83-8530-840469ae6f48/   https://web.archive.org/web/20220106175030/https://www.offida.info/covid-record-di-contagi-in-italia-e-nelle-marche/

A wide variety of businesses â including gyms and fitness centers, pools, beaches, cultural facilities, museums, exhibits, entertainment centers, religious facilities, some movie theaters, food courts, and recreational facilities â are open, subject to participation in Ashyq, to increasing restrictions on hours of operations, and to capacity limitations due to the detection of the omicron variant in Kazakhstan. However, some regional and local governments periodically impose restrictions in response to increases in the infection rate.    Ashyq Application:  Businesses that would otherwise be closed or subject to opening and/or occupancy restrictions may open under less restrictive conditions by participating in âAshyq,â an application that displays a color-coded risk status for each visitor based on information in Ministry of Health COVID-19 infection, PCR test, and vaccination databases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106223333/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

All large events and family gatherings are prohibited. Individual and group outdoor fitness activities are permitted, and people may walk in parks and other public spaces in groups of three or less.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106223333/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Is public transportation operating?  Yes  The Chief Sanitary Doctor of Kazakhstan has mandated that masks be worn nationwide in public settings, including both indoor and outdoor spaces and on public transportation.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012336/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  The city of Nur-Sultan and the regions of Akmola, Karaganda, Kostanay, and Pavlodar are classified as yellow zones. Some additional measures are typically enforced in yellow zones:  Public transport operates from 06:00-23:00 Monday-Saturday and is suspended on Sundays.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211220054019/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551076/kazakhstan-authorities-announce-tightening-of-international-entry-restrictions-due-to-omicron-covid-19-variant-from-dec-3-update-50

Is public transportation operating?  Yes  https://web.archive.org/web/20220106223333/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    Public transport operates from 06:00-23:00 Monday-Saturday and is suspended on Sundays  https://web.archive.org/web/20220102065005/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551076/kazakhstan-authorities-announce-tightening-of-international-entry-restrictions-due-to-omicron-covid-19-variant-from-dec-3-update-50

Nationwide, authorities require residents to obtain a government-provided QR code via the Ashyq mobile application to visit government offices and certain public spaces, including leisure facilities, cultural venues, and entertainment establishments. Ashyq codes are also required to gain entry to international airports in Almaty and Nur-Sultan. Residents will have their app scanned at each establishment; each QR code scan will reveal a resident's color-coded risk rating:    Red - movement restricted to self-isolation regime    Yellow - movement partially restricted; essential trips to nearest pharmacy and grocery store permitted    Blue - no specific restrictions    Green - no specific restrictions, and the user has a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test.    Authorities could reimpose, extend, further ease, or otherwise amend any restrictions with little-to-no notice depending on disease activity over the coming weeks.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211220054019/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551076/kazakhstan-authorities-announce-tightening-of-international-entry-restrictions-due-to-omicron-covid-19-variant-from-dec-3-update-50

Nationwide, authorities require residents to obtain a government-provided QR code via the Ashyq mobile application to visit government offices and certain public spaces, including leisure facilities, cultural venues, and entertainment establishments. Ashyq codes are also required to gain entry to international airports in Almaty and Nur-Sultan. Residents will have their app scanned at each establishment; each QR code scan will reveal a resident's color-coded risk rating:    Red - movement restricted to self-isolation regime    Yellow - movement partially restricted; essential trips to nearest pharmacy and grocery store permitted    Blue - no specific restrictions    Green - no specific restrictions, and the user has a negative result from a COVID-19 PCR test.

Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel?  Yes, in some cases.  As of May 11, 2021, the Government of Kazakhstan began prohibiting people who accompany departing travelers or meet arriving passengers from entering airports and rail stations in regions in high risk âRed Zones.â An exception exists for airports and rail stations participating in the âAshyqâ application system (please see further information on âAshyqâ in the Quarantine Information paragraph below).  Kazakhstanâs regions are empowered to take additional measures to combat the spread of COVID-19 as necessary, including erecting checkpoints to limit travel in and out of cities and oblasts.  Before pursuing domestic travel in Kazakhstan, we urge you to research whether checkpoints might be in place that could restrict your ability to travel.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012336/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

We remind you that the Kazakhstani border remains closed to foreigners with limited exceptions, including diplomats, direct-family members of Kazakhstani citizens, residency permit holders, some employees of designated companies in critical industries, and citizens of those countries with which Kazakhstan has resumed direct flights.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20220108012336/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Kazakhstan will tighten international entry restrictions from Dec. 3 over concerns regarding the recently identified Omicron variant of COVID-19. From this date, nonresident foreign nationals from the following countries are prohibited from entry: South Africa, Botswana, Lesotho, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Madagascar, eSwatini, Malawi, Tanzania, and Hong Kong. Additionally, travelers from countries that have declared the presence of the Omicron variant must - regardless of vaccination status - present a negative PCR test and self-isolate for seven days on arrival; these countries currently include Australia, Belgium, the UK, Czech Republic, Germany, Egypt, Israel, Italy, Canada, and the Netherlands.    Other international entry restrictions remain in effect. Visa-free travel remains suspended. However, flights with several countries have resumed, including Belarus, Egypt, Germany, South Korea, Kyrgyzstan, the Netherlands, Russia, Turkey, Ukraine, the UAE, and Uzbekistan, though capacity is likely to be limited. Some routes may also be suspended in the wake of the new entry restrictions.    As of Nov. 30, all international arrivals must provide a vaccination certificate or evidence of a negative COVID-19 test taken no more than 72 hours before entry into Kazakhstan.   https://web.archive.org/web/20220102065005/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551076/kazakhstan-authorities-announce-tightening-of-international-entry-restrictions-due-to-omicron-covid-19-variant-from-dec-3-update-50

No manual contact tracing.     However the Ashyq app is available:    "The mobile application "Ashyq" enables through the use of a QR code and integration with the general database of the Ministry of Health of the Republic of Kazakhstan, to determine the status of a visitor: whether he is currently a carrier of the virus or not.    For the businesses, this makes it possible to continue their activities during the period of quarantine measures, as well as minimizes the risks of the spread of Covid-19 and reduces the number of contacts leading to infection.    The use of the application for both entrepreneurs and citizens is free.    Today, every person who becomes ill with COVID-19 in any form (symptomatic or asymptomatic) undertakes to comply with the home quarantine regime and assures them with a personal signature on the receipt. However, we often come across facts of violation of the self-isolation regime."    Archived web link: https://web.archive.org/web/20211105195803/https://egov.kz/cms/en/articles/prilozhenie-ashyq

Vaccines: Sputnik V, QazVac, CoronaVac and Sinopharm.    Quote: "Has the government of Kazakhstan approved a COVID-19 vaccine for use?  Yes  Are vaccines available in Kazakhstan for U.S. citizens to receive?  Yes, for permanent residents (see below).  Which vaccines are available in Kazakhstan? Sputnik V, QazVac, CoronaVac and Sinopharm.  On April 7, 2021, the Minister of Health announced in a press briefing that foreigners who live and work in Kazakhstan and have permanent residence cards may receive COVID-19 vaccination free of charge just like Kazakhstani citizens.  Currently, the only record of this announcement is in media reporting.  The Ministry of Health of Kazakhstan initiated a multi-stage vaccination program on February 1, 2021"  Archive Link  https://web.archive.org/web/20211123093223/https://kz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

Schools are open but masks must be worn indoors. Contact service will be provided in schools. No change policy.   In Chisinau, 20 educational institutions operate in a mixed system and more than 1,700 pupils study online.  At the same time, 20 municipal institutions continue to operate in a mixed regime and 1,700 pupils continue to study online. The measure is due to the large number of students in the class, which makes it impossible to be physically present in the classroom without violating anti-coronavirus prevention measures.  Source: https://archive.ph/QFpHb  Schooling is both online and in-person.   Source: https://archive.ph/bwDU3

No policy changes.  Domestic Restrictions. Authorities have extended the nationwide state of public health emergency (SoE) until at least Jan. 15 due to rising COVID-19 cases; the SoE was previously slated to expire Nov. 30. As part of their attempts to curb the recent surge in infections, officials will continue to enforce restrictions on the use of certain facilities and on indoor and outdoor mass events.   Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211221145827/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/551411/moldova-authorities-tighten-covid-19-related-international-entry-restrictions-for-travelers-from-eight-african-nations-as-of-nov-30-update-24

The government has extended the state of emergency until March 15th.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220114124622/https://msmps.gov.md/comunicare/comunicate/cnesp-a-decis-prelungirea-starii-de-urgenta-in-sanatate-publica/

The National Public Health Emergency Commission in Moldova extended the National State of Public Health Emergency. Announcements from the Commission and restrictions under the ongoing State of Public Health Emergency are available on the Government of Moldova website.  Face-masks are mandatory in all public indoor spaces.    Chisinau has a mask mandate for open-air public events, as well as social-distancing rules.  Additional restrictions could be lifted or (re)imposed with little notice.  Moldovan authorities established new public health measures to limit the spread of COVID-19 infection at all public events and gatherings, both indoor and outdoor.  Anyone over the age of 18 eating in a restaurant or cafÃ© or attending any show, concert, festival, theater, cinema, concert hall, nightclub, dance floor, etc., must present one of the following documents: 1) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 2) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.   Source: https://archive.ph/WIEbZ (Last updated: January 08, 2022).

Anyone over the age of 18 eating in a restaurant or cafÃ© or attending any show, concert, festival, theater, cinema, concert hall, nightclub, dance floor, etc., must present one of the following documents: 1) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 2) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date. In addition, the government has extended the state of emergency until March 15th.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220114124622/https://msmps.gov.md/comunicare/comunicate/cnesp-a-decis-prelungirea-starii-de-urgenta-in-sanatate-publica/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220125001334/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

Additional restrictions could be lifted or (re)imposed with little notice.  Source: https://archive.ph/WIEbZ (Last updated: January 08, 2022).

Private events (festive meals, corporate parties, weddings, baptisms) with 25 or more participants will still be allowed only with their presentation of the COVID-19 certificate, in the green and yellow alert thresholds.   In the orange and red alert thresholds, the rules for private events do not change. Thus, in the orange threshold they are allowed only with the presentation by the participants of the COVID-19 certificate, and in the red alert threshold they remain forbidden.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220114124622/https://msmps.gov.md/comunicare/comunicate/cnesp-a-decis-prelungirea-starii-de-urgenta-in-sanatate-publica/

Effective November 28, 2021, Moldova banned entry to foreigners who were physically present in the last 14 days in South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Namibia, Eswatini, or Malawi.   Source: https://archive.vn/kxfbF (Last updated: December 31, 2021).

Effective November 28, 2021, Moldova banned entry to foreigners who were physically present in the last 14 days in South Africa, Lesotho, Botswana, Zimbabwe, Mozambique, Namibia, Eswatini, or Malawi. Source: https://archive.ph/WIEbZ (Last updated: January 08, 2022).

No entry bans from any country. The following rules applied to over 50 countries until January 17th and applies to all countries since then: Moldova requires anyone entering the country present one of the following:  1) a COVID-19 vaccine certificate (valid 14 days after the second dose); 2) a negative PCR COVID-19 test (taken in the last 72 hours) or an antigen test (taken in the last 48 hours); 3) a medical certificate attesting the person had COVID-19 in the previous 6 months; or 4) a COVID-19 antibodies certificate valid for 90 days from the exam date.  Any COVID-19 antibodies certificate or evidence of vaccination must be in Romanian, English, French, German, Italian, or Russian language.  Moldovan Border Police accept all types of vaccination with appropriate documentation.  Absent one of the documents listed above, a traveler will have to self-isolate for 14 days.  Self-isolation may be discontinued after 7 days if a COVID-19 PCR test or a rapid SARS-CoV-2 Ag test is performed, and the result is negative based on a confirmative document.  If you are subject to self-isolation and depart Moldova, you could be fined for violating self-isolation.  Anyone required to self-isolate should complete an online epidemiological card 3 days before arriving in Moldova.  https://web.archive.org/web/20220125001334/https://md.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/web/20220107182222/https://msmps.gov.md/comunicare/lista-statelor-cu-risc-epidemiologic-sporit-de-transmitere-a-infectiei-covid-l9-2/

No changes in policy.  Key Policy Responses as of July 1, 2021. A comprehensive fiscal package has been adopted as per two 2020 State Budget Amendments, following several targeted fiscal measures to support businesses and vulnerable households, such as expanding unemployment benefits and strengthening existing targeted social assistance, tax relief for sectors affected by state-imposed restrictions, delaying tax payment deadlines to mid-2020, suspending tax audits and other controls, and increasing state budget allocations to the budget emergency and health funds and to a mortgage guarantee program. The approved 2021 Budget envisages more support to the health sector, and farmers support.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20211221154516/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

No changes.  Negotiations between the IMF mission and the Moldovan Government have successfully ended with a stafflevel agreement for Moldova to access 564 M USD. The programme will be implemented in a time span of 40 months and is subject to the implementation of several prior actions, including on central bank independence, the correction of past policy slippages, and the adoption of credible fiscal plans. Also, Moldova will use the Special Drawing Rights of the International Monetary Fund IMF), to finance the state budgetâs needs, with about US$236 million to be allocated to finance the necessities of Moldovaâs state budget.  Source: https://archive.ph/gR5ei

"Daycare centres for children aged 0 to 4 are open.  From Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022 primary schools and schools for special primary education will be closed. Out-of-school care facilities (BSO) will also be closed.  Schools will be open to provide emergency childcare for vulnerable children and the children of key workers in crucial sectors.   BSO facilities are only open during this period to provide emergency childcare.  Schools that are unable to put this emergency childcare into place in time must close no later than Tuesday 21 December 2021, as must out-of-school care facilities.   Secondary schools will be closed from Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022.  Secondary vocational institutions  (MBO) will be closed from Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022.  Higher education institutions (HBO and universities) will be closed from Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022.  Accredited (further) education may take place in the evenings."    https://archive.fo/BC5gS

Out-of-school care centres (BSO) will also be closed. Primary schools, schools for special education and out-of-school care centres will reopen on 10 January 2022.  Secondary schools and special secondary schools will be closed from Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022. These schools will reopen on 10 January 2022.  Schools for secondary vocational education (MBO) will be closed from Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022. These schools will offer remote learning from 10 January 2022.  Higher education institutions (HBO and universities) will be closed from Monday 20 December 2021 to Sunday 9 January 2022. They will offer remote learning from 10 January 2022."  https://archive.fo/LPiIo

"The special entry restrictions that were introduced for travellers arriving from 8 countries in Southern Africa at the end of November will be removed. The measures were introduced to limit and delay the spread of the Omicron variant. The Norwegian Government is keeping the strict general entry restrictions that apply to arrival in Norway.  âOmicron is now established in many countries, including Norway. The Norwegian Directorate of Health and the Norwegian Institute of Public Health believe that it is no longer expedient to keep specific measures that target travellers from these 8 countries. This is why the special measures are being removed. We are also keeping the strict general entry restrictions that apply to arrival in Norway,â says Minister of Health and Care Services Ingvild Kjerkol.  The special measures targeted travellers arriving from South Africa, Mozambique, Namibia, Zimbabwe, Botswana, Lesotho, Eswatini, and Malawi, where the virus variant was discovered. The change will enter into effect on 22 December at 12 am."    "Measures that will be kept  The strict general entry measures that apply to arrival in Norway will be kept. They include:  a requirement of entry registration for all travellers;    a general requirement for all travellers to get tested upon arrival in Norway;    a requirement of documentation of a negative test taken before arrival for people who cannot produce a verifiable COVID-19 certificate showing that they are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 during the past 6 months;    travel quarantine for people who arrive from a country that triggers a duty to quarantine and who cannot produce a verifiable COVID-19 certificate showing that they are fully vaccinated or have recovered from COVID-19 during the past 6 months."  https://archive.fo/upo3s#selection-1393.1-1427.243

21/1/22  Education  All students returned to full-time teaching.    Find out more about school rules.    Nurseries and kindergartens  Nurseries and kindergartens are open and provide care for children.    Illness, quarantine or isolation of the child  A person covered by sickness insurance is entitled to an allowance in the event of a need to care for a sick child, including when the child has been subject to isolation or quarantine. Care allowance may also be used by a parent who has to look after a healthy child up to the age of 8 due to the unexpected closure of the institution the child attends.    You can learn more about the care allowance on the ZUS website .    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121112116/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/opieka-i-edukacja

14/1/22  Social distance and masks in place     Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  Only cover the nose and mouth with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / customer service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.    https://archive.fo/yBRsI

21/1/22  Social distance and face masks  Restrictions on movement  1.5 meters - the minimum distance between pedestrians  Obligation to maintain a distance of at least 1.5 meters between pedestrians.    The following are excluded from this obligation:    parents with children requiring care (up to 13 years of age),  people living together or running a farm,  people with a disability certificate, people with a disability degree, people with a certificate of need for special education, people who are unable to move independently and their guardians.  Covering the mouth and nose only with a mask  Covering the mouth and nose in confined spaces is mandatory throughout the country.  The nose and mouth may only be covered with a mask. Scarves, visors and dishes are not allowed because they do not fulfill their primary function, i.e. they do not protect against the virus!    The mouth and nose must be covered, for example:    on the premises of shared properties (e.g. in the staircase),  on the bus, tram and train,  in a shop, shopping mall, bank, market and post office,  in the workplace, if there is more than 1 person in the room (unless the employer decides otherwise),  in the workplace during direct customer / client service,  in the cinema and theater,  at the doctor's, clinic, hospital, massage and tattoo parlor,  in the church and school, at the university  in offices and other public buildings (in court, cultural institutions, banks, post offices, etc.)  in schools and universities during breaks between lessons and classes, unless otherwise decided by the head of the entity.  Where do you not need to cover your mouth and nose?    In the open air, in the forest, park, greenery, botanical gardens, historic gardens, on roads and squares, in cemeteries, promenades, boulevards, parking places for vehicles, forest parking lots, in family allotments and on the beach, and during private travel by car, motorcycle, quadricycle, moped, at the workplace to eat.     Detailed information on covering the mouth and nose as well as information on exceptions to this rule can be found in the regulation .    Important! Only persons with a medical certificate or a document confirming:    pervasive development disorders,  mental disorders,  moderate, severe or severe intellectual disability,  difficulty uncovering or covering your mouth or nose on your own.  advanced neurological, respiratory or circulatory disorders with respiratory or circulatory failure.    https://web.archive.org/web/20220121112908/https://www.gov.pl/web/koronawirus/dystans-spoleczny-i-maseczki

5/1/22  Locations are open but with a capacity limit on those not vaccinated.    culture and entertainment  Museums and art galleries  They function in a strict sanitary regime. There is a limit of people - 1 person. for 15 m 2 .    Attention! The number of persons vaccinated against COVID-19 is not counted if they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Cinemas  They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose.    It is not allowed to eat or drink in the cinemas.    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Theaters, operas, philharmonics  Outdoor:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners.    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    In rooms:    They operate in a strict sanitary regime - max. 30 percent. occupancy. Maintain a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners. Ensuring that there is no more than 1 person in the room at the same time per 15 m2 of its surface. It is necessary to cover the mouth and nose    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services. Ensure that participants follow the order to cover their mouth and nose.    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Concerts and circus performances  Events may take place under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,  keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience and ensure that no more than 1 person per 15 square meters is present in the room at the same time,  ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.  Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Concerts and circus performances may be organized outdoors under the following conditions:    making available to viewers or listeners no more than 30 percent. number of seats,  keep a distance of 1.5 m between viewers or listeners in the absence of designated seats in the audience,  ensure that viewers or listeners comply with the order to cover their mouth and nose.  Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Outdoor amusement parks  Amusement parks may operate at up to 30%. occupancy.    Attention! The 30% limit does not include those vaccinated against COVID-19 provided that they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.    Libraries  Possibility to make collections available, provided that no more than 1 person per 15 mÂ² is present in the library, with the exception of librarians. Before entering the library, information about the limit of people should be posted.         Conducting activities by public and scientific libraries consisting in the organization of meetings and events is allowed indoors, provided that:    while maintaining a distance of 1.5 m between participants;  that participants comply with the obligation to cover their mouth and nose.       Attention! The number of persons vaccinated against COVID-19 is not counted if they show:    EU digital COVID certificate;  or a certificate of vaccination, test result and recovery.  If the indicated documents are not presented, the entrepreneur has the right to refuse to provide services.
